summary_variants.short_answer: Blue Zones are regions popularized by researchers where communities reportedly have higher life expectancy and concentrations of centenarians.
summary_variants.kid_friendly: Blue Zones are places where lots of people live to be very old, often because they eat mostly plants, move every day, and stay close with friends and family.
summary_variants.standard: Blue Zones refer to geographic areas identified by Dan Buettner and colleagues where residents appear to reach age 90 or 100 at higher-than-average rates. Proposed contributors include plant-forward diets, daily low-intensity activity, community support, and limited smoking, though data quality has been debated.
summary_variants.expert_notes: Outline Ikaria, Okinawa, Sardinia, Nicoya, and Loma Linda; discuss demographic methods, selection bias critiques, and the difference between marketing narratives and peer-reviewed epidemiology.

slots.definition: Named regions where observational data suggests above-average longevity and atypically high numbers of nonagenarians and centenarians.
key_characteristics: Plant-heavy diets with modest caloric intake
Daily low-intensity physical activity embedded in routines
Strong social cohesion, faith communities, and purpose-driven lifestyles
Limited tobacco use and moderate alcohol consumption
applications: Public-health storytelling to encourage lifestyle changes
Community design initiatives inspired by Blue Zones Project
limitations: Age-record validation challenges in historical registries
Selection and survivorship biases in identifying exemplar communities
Difficult to isolate causal factors from correlated cultural traits
history: Demographers Gianni Pes and Michel Poulain highlighted Sardinia's longevity clusters (early 2000s)
Dan Buettner popularized the term Blue Zones through National Geographic articles and books (2005 onward)
Follow-on community interventions launched in multiple U.S. cities via the Blue Zones Project
